Key Arguments: The Bill is seen as a form of censorship that limits free speech.
Definitions of misinformation and disinformation are inadequate and open to bias.
The Bill could be used to protect government agendas and those of influential parties.
The necessity and purpose of the Bill are not clearly explained.
The Bill's exclusion of government and news services from its scope is criticized.
The Bill could lead to digital platforms acting as 'thought police' and being overly conservative.
Historical examples are used to argue that authorities can be wrong about what constitutes misinformation.
Main Themes: Role and Responsibility of Digital Platforms
Notable Quotes: The Bill amounts to a covert form of censorship that is unwelcome and will in fact limit free speech.
The legislation thus assumes that Governments can never be ‘wrong’ which we know not to be true.
The Bill is dangerous in that it puts the onus on the digital service providers to determine what is or isn’t mis/disinformation and effectively turns them into defacto thought police.

To think that 'the authorities' have a sufficient grasp of what’s true and what’s not, or that they don’t have agendas to protect, is arrogant and provides a greater danger than the Bill reportedly seeks to prevent.
